author: By Marc Santora
title: With Slow Advance, Ukraine Aims for Better Shot at Russian Targets
description: Ukraine is hoping that mile-by-mile gains could bring its weapons closer to Russian supply lines, if its forces can overcome Russia’s heavy defense.
content: Ukrainian officials have cautioned that their drive toward the Sea of Azov, a key objective of their counteroffensive, will require a bloody slog through extensive minefields and fortified trenches, likely under heavy artillery fire along roads lined with Russian armor and machine guns. But Kyiv has a more immediate goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Heat Records Are Falling Worldwide, but Most Californians Have Been Spared
description: Some California regions have experienced heat waves, but most of the state has not had to endure the sweltering stretches felt elsewhere this summer.
content: It’s Friday. July has been record hot across the globe, but most Californians have been spared. Plus, San Francisco’s district attorney condemns recent attacks on older Asian Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: John Fetterman, Hoodie and All, Is Adjusting to Life in the Senate
description: In an interview with The New York Times, the Pennsylvania senator spoke about the dysfunction in Congress, his health challenges and why he hasn’t traded his loungewear for a business suit.
content: It has been an unusual first six months in Congress for Senator John Fetterman, the 6-foot-8, tattooed Democrat from Pennsylvania, who moved to Washington in January after suffering a near-fatal stroke on the campaign trail last year and going on to win one of the most competitive seats in the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
title: Economic Data Bolster Soft Landing Hopes
description: A key inflation gauge moderated and wage growth has cooled, even as consumers have continued to spend resiliently.
content: Falling inflation. Moderating wage growth. Resilient consumer spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Does This Brooklyn Housing Development Know the Secret to Long Life?
description: A project in East New York aims to to adapt the ethos of Blue Zones — healthy, close-knit communities where people live to 100 — to one of the poorest neighborhoods in the city.
content: Ever since researchers identified a handful of places around the world where people lived remarkably long, healthy lives, there have been efforts to replicate the magic recipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: An ‘Oppenheimer’ Reading List
description: Seeing the new Christopher Nolan film about the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, and the project to build the first atomic bomb? Our columnist has some recommendations for reading.
content: Some movies make me want to seek out further reading as a way to linger in their universes a little longer, spending more time with beloved characters and glamorous settings. “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s biopic about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the scientist known as “the father of the atomic bomb,” is not one of those movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: ‘X’ Marks the Spot
description: Elon Musk’s decision to ditch the Twitter brand is confusing on many levels.
content: Don’t know if you heard, but Twitter is X now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart say: Come on in. The puzzle’s fine!
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is about the world’s oceans and their most feared denizens. It’s from a 2011 book called “Demon Fish” by Juliet Eilperin, who is the deputy climate and environment editor at The Washington Post. The fish in question is a shark, of course.It’s midsummer now, and the odds are probably at their peak that your toes are somewhere near the water while you solve this acrostic (cue the John Williams music). Fear not: Eilperin’s book provides a wider perspective on how important sharks are to the balance of the marine ecosystem and informs us that only about 6 percent of sharks pose any danger to humans (and that we are far more likely to get struck by lightning than wind up in a shark’s jaws).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why ‘Soft Landing’ Optimists Shouldn’t Celebrate Just Yet
description: Despite a barrage of interest-rate increases, the economy is faring better than many on Wall Street had imagined. But the wild card of inflation still looms.
content: With the S&P 500 in bull-market territory, corporate profits coming in better than expected and surprisingly decent economic growth, the soft-landing optimists are feeling pretty good about the direction of the economy. But their position will be tested as soon as Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Billy Witz
title: Abuse and Racism Accusations Bring ‘#MeToo Moment’ to Northwestern
description: In lawsuits, former athletes accuse the sports program of having a pervasive culture of hazing and sexual abuse, and two coaches have been fired. Lawyers say more athletes may come forward.
content: It was the sixth lawsuit against Northwestern University in nine days, and the allegations had become, somehow, both familiar and even more appalling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Buchanan
title: The Lost Art of Fouling the Ball Off (on Purpose)
description: Spoiling difficult pitches to stay alive was equal parts strategy and party trick. The modern approach to hitting has left it behind.
content: He stood 5 feet 7 inches tall and had an unforgettably French Canadian name — Pierre LePage — but his skill with a bat was what made a lasting impression. His hand-eye coordination beggared belief, and it was matched with his barrel control. In three seasons at the University of Connecticut, he batted .336. In his junior year, he took 248 trips to the plate and struck out only three times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: He Held Up a Bank to Get His Own Money
description: Amid severe limits on withdrawals and a yearslong financial crisis, Lebanese depositors are resorting to force to demand their own money, earning the moniker “the world’s most honorable bank robbers.”
content: By the time Walid al-Hajjar stormed his bank armed with a jug of gasoline, four lighters and a willingness to set himself on fire, his wife’s bone cancer was too far gone for him to save her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: kaput
description: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word kaput has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 19 in “Houston and Alabama Size Each Other Up From the Same Arena” by Billy Witz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: As Heat Waves Intensify, Europe’s Cities Rely on Age-Old Ways to Stay Cool
description: Architectural styles and construction materials can significantly reduce the need for air-conditioning during heat waves, according to sustainable architecture experts.
content: There is no single architectural technique that can solve the problem of sweltering heat, which has gripped large parts of Europe this summer. But on a continent where air-conditioning is relatively limited, sustainable building techniques can go a long way in protecting residents, according to experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Biden Acknowledges Granddaughter in Arkansas for First Time
description: The president has told his son, Hunter Biden, that he wants to meet his 4-year-old grandchild, Navy Joan Roberts, who until recently was at the center of a yearslong child support dispute.
content: President Biden publicly acknowledged his 4-year-old granddaughter, Navy Joan Roberts, for the first time on Friday, saying in a statement that he and the first lady, Jill Biden, “only want what is best for all of our grandchildren, including Navy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: As His Campaign Craters, DeSantis Walls Himself In
description: Ron DeSantis is selling the wrong message to Republicans, but he’s too deep in his bubble to realize it.
content: As he flails to reverse a polling decline that is beginning to resemble a rockslide, Gov. Ron DeSantis must be feeling a little clueless about why his political fortunes are crumbling so quickly. Attacking wokeness and bullying transgender people seemed to work so well in Florida, so why aren’t national Republicans in awe of the divisions he’s deepened? Making repeated appearances with racial provocateurs never stopped him from getting elected as governor, so why did he have to fire a young aide who inserted Nazi imagery into his own video promoting Mr. DeSantis’s presidential campaign?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Mastercard Moves to Stop Use of Debit Cards at Cannabis Shops
description: The decision places more strain on the cannabis industry, which largely operates with cash and is not uniformly regulated across the United States. The drug is still illegal on the federal level.
content: Mastercard instructed U.S. financial institutions this week to stop allowing purchases of cannabis on its debit cards, stripping customers of a convenient way to purchase marijuana without cash. Cannabis businesses say the decision will increase the risk of robbery and violent crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Ritzy Crab Dip, Chapli Burgers and Cold Noodles With Tomatoes
description: What to cook on these long summer weekends.
content: Good morning. A very long time ago, the novelist Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings came up with a great recipe for crab Newburg, based on the lobster version once served at Delmonico’s in New York. It’s a highlight of “Cross Creek Cookery,” her memoir of cooking life in backcountry Florida before World War II: a shockingly rich amalgam of crab and cream and sherry, best served over toast points or in a puff pastry shell. It is high-WASP nursery food, not terribly difficult to prepare, an old-school preparation that is like a black-tie version of this excellent baked crab dip (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: A Tiny Cabin, a Little Island and a Big Change: ‘Am I Crazy?’
description: A New Jersey woman now lives alone part of the year on a remote island in Maine that Stephen King called ‘a novel here, just waiting to be written.’
content: “Duck Ledges Island,” the listing read, “offered in its entirety.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: He Created the Katamari Games, but They’re Rolling On Without Him
description: Twenty years after his quirky project Katamari Damacy delighted the video game industry, Keita Takahashi is an independent designer who receives no royalties for his debut work.
content: Keita Takahashi did not want to say much before an official announcement for his upcoming project except that it would include a boy and his dog. Yet the creations by one of the video game industry’s most eccentric designers are never that straightforward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The Dance Delight in ‘Barbie’ Belongs to the Kens
description: The most majestic dance in “Barbie” is an emotional release for the Kens, but in subtle ways movement touches, and enhances, everything in the movie.
content: There’s a gorgeous scene in “Barbie” that isn’t painted the usual pink. It isn’t dripping in plastic or sequins. It’s a dream ballet, stylish and clean, with steps so sleek it lets bodies — Kens, Kens and more Kens — sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Betsy Bonner
title: Three Debuts Explore the Trials — and Horrors — of Growing Up
description: From a house haunted by phantom children to younger siblings haunted by sexual trauma, three new novels feature protagonists struggling to be or raise kids.
content: Time behaves erratically at the Reeve, the cliff-top mansion in Kate Collins’s A GOOD HOUSE FOR CHILDREN (Mariner, 325 pp., $30), a feminist gothic that evokes Shirley Jackson’s “The Haunting of Hill House.” Set in Dorset, England, the novel follows two different groups of the house’s inhabitants at different moments in time: Orla and Nick and their two children in 2017; and the nanny Lydia, her grieving widow boss, Sara, and Sara’s four children in 1976.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Passes Bipartisan Defense Bill, Setting Up a Clash With the House
description: Senators steered clear of the social policy dictates that sapped Democratic support for the House bill, but the legislation was headed for a contentious negotiation to reach a final agreement.
content: The Senate on Thursday gave overwhelming approval to the annual defense policy bill, sidestepping a contentious debate over abortion access for service members and quashing efforts to limit aid for Ukraine in a show of bipartisanship that set up a bitter showdown with the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Unhappy With Right-Wing Leaders, Some Israelis Hatch Escape Plans
description: Reacting to efforts by the government to take greater control of the judiciary, some people are transferring money overseas and applying for other passports if they are eligible.
content: Naama Levin and her partner had always dreamed about taking a break from Israel and going on an extended vacation abroad. But they did not start making concrete plans until late last year, when Benjamin Netanyahu returned to power and formed a coalition with extreme right-wing and religiously conservative partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: What Spence-Crawford Lacks in Trash Talk, It Makes Up in Talent
description: Errol Spence Jr. and Terence Crawford haven’t hyped their title fight with antagonistic displays. Promoters are banking that the bout between the undefeated welterweights will sell itself.
content: If the tension that accompanies the highest-stakes prizefight of the year was affecting Errol Spence Jr. and Terence Crawford, who planned to fight for the undisputed welterweight championship on Saturday night, neither boxer let it show until their final meeting with reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Defiant Netanyahu Defends Judicial Overhaul in Israel
description: The prime minister said he planned to reinstate an ally barred from the government. He declined to say if he would respect a Supreme Court decision on the overhaul plan that has divided the country.
content: Just days after his coalition passed the first stage of a judicial overhaul plan that has divided the country, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel struck a defiant tone, saying he hoped to reinstate a key ally convicted of a felony and declining to say if he would respect a Supreme Court ruling on the plan if it did not go his way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Randy Meisner, a Founding Member of the Eagles, Dies at 77
description: The group’s original bass player, he was a member from 1971 to 1977, but he was never one to jostle for the spotlight.
content: Randy Meisner, a founding member and the original bassist of the Eagles whose celestial tenor fueled hits like “Take It to the Limit” and helped catapult the breezy country-rock band from the Los Angeles club circuit to the pinnacle of 1970s rock, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Luckerson
title: Everything They Owned Burned, and They Still Can’t Get Restitution 102 Years Later
description: After the Tulsa Race Massacre, the courts refused to punish the attackers or offer redress to hundreds of newly destitute people. This injustice continues.
content: Among the most famous images related to the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre is a photo of two Black attorneys sitting in a tent among the smoldered ruins of the Greenwood District. The date is June 6, 1921, less than a week after a white mob razed Greenwood, a thriving Oklahoma community known as Black Wall Street. The men, B.C. Franklin and I.H. Spears, are surrounded by salvaged law books and a diligent secretary sitting before a lone typewriter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Exxon Reports Leaner Earnings in Second Quarter
description: The company’s record profit a year earlier was driven by a surge in oil prices after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Exxon Mobil, the largest American oil company, announced on Friday that its profit was $7.9 billion in the second quarter, down from a record $17.9 billion in the second quarter of 2022 and $11.4 billion in the first quarter of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Lonely Voice for Change, Until Her Country Changed With Her
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 28, 2023.
content: “She was still on the edge. But much of Ireland moved over, and joined her.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: We Know What Happens When We Prosecute Drug Dealers as Murderers
description: The opioid epidemic is a nightmare. Revisiting draconian drug sentencing laws will make it worse.
content: Stories of narcotics-related death and debasement flooded the media. Politicians stoked panic about marijuana. Parents feared that teenagers would tip into addiction. Congress held hearings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Alexandra Berzon
title: The Mystery of How Tim Scott’s Campaign Is Spending Its Millions
description: Most of the money spent by the senator’s presidential campaign has gone to newly formed companies whose addresses are Staples stores in suburban strip malls.
content: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina has more political money than most of his Republican presidential rivals, and he has not been shy about spending it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Is That Water Too Polluted to Swim in?
description: Taking a dip at the wrong time or place can make you sick — here’s what to look out for.
content: In recent weeks, floods in the Northeast have led to dozens of beach closures. Heavy rainfall and flooding increase the risk that water will be contaminated with disease-causing pathogens that people can accidentally ingest while swimming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Friend Is Trapped in a Nursing Home. What Can I Do?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping people who are institutionalized against their will.
content: Five years ago, I began volunteering as a bill payer for a legally blind, 95-year-old woman on public assistance. The job involved handling paperwork that clients could no longer handle themselves, thus helping enable them to remain at home. I came to learn that this woman had no family or friends left, and she came to think of me as her only friend. During my time with her, she was also put under the care of Adult Protective Services (A.P.S.), because one of her caregivers was fraudulently using her credit card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Trump Faces New Charges in Mar-a-Lago Case, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 50 Rappers, 50 Stories: Hear the Remix
description: Ten bonus songs from our hip-hop anniversary project.
content: Last week, the Times published a sprawling interactive package called 50 Rappers, 50 Stories, celebrating the upcoming 50th anniversary of hip-hop.* The day it ran, I set aside about 10 minutes to start browsing during lunch; the next thing I knew, more than an hour and a half had passed. It’s one of those kinds of projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski
title: Ukraine Launches Rare Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says
description: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
content: Moscow said it shot down two Ukrainian missiles over southwestern Russia on Friday, including one that fell and exploded in a city center — apparently rare instances of Ukraine using such powerful weapons to attack targets inside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: A Recipe for Love? Add ‘Water and Sunlight.’
description: Before meeting Jennifer Ziegler, Rebecca Woodfork said she was always “looking down and getting through life.” One month together in Boston and a trip to St. Lucia changed that.
content: Rebecca Ann Woodfork and Jennifer Kathryn Ziegler had been talking on the phone daily for about six weeks when Ms. Ziegler, who lived in New York City, suggested she visit Ms. Woodfork in Boston for her 40th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller and Jillian Weinberger
title: The Conditions Are Ripe for a Third Party in 2024. Is No Labels It?
description: Katherine Miller shares her impressions after attending the nonpartisan group’s first town hall.
content: A majority of Americans don’t want to see President Biden and former President Trump compete for the White House again in 2024. No Labels, a nonpartisan political group, is talking about running a third-party unity ticket next year if Joe Biden and Donald Trump are the nominees. The Opinion writer and editor Katherine Miller has been reporting on a potential third option, and attended the first No Labels town hall in New Hampshire. In this audio short, Miller argues the group has failed to make the case that it holds a viable solution to voter unease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: With Actors on Strike, Sony Pushes Big Releases to 2024
description: The union has barred members from publicizing their work, and without red carpets and the buzz machine in full swing, other studios are likely to follow.
content: Hollywood studios, scrambling to contend with a strike by unionized actors, have started to remove big-budget movies from the 2023 release calendar, newly imperiling theaters and undoubtedly irritating fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Adams
title: Make It New and Difficult: The Music of Arnold Schoenberg
description: John Adams reviews “Schoenberg: Why He Matters,” in which Harvey Sachs explores the artistic, academic and spiritual life of a 20th-century cultural giant.
content: In 1955 Henry Pleasants, a critic of both popular and classical music, issued a cranky screed of a book, “The Agony of Modern Music,” which opened with the implacable verdict that “serious music is a dead art.” Pleasants’s thesis was that the traditional forms of classical music — opera, oratorio, orchestral and chamber music, all constructions of a bygone era — no longer related to the experience of our modern lives. Composers had lost touch with the currents of popular taste, and popular music, with its vitality and its connection to the spirit of the times, had dethroned the classics. Absent the mass appeal enjoyed by past masters like Beethoven, Verdi, Wagner and Tchaikovsky, modern composers had retreated into obscurantism, condemned to a futile search for novelty amid the detritus of a tradition that was, like overworked soil, exhausted and fallow. One could still love classical music, but only with the awareness that it was a relic of the past and in no way representative of our contemporary experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Lyster
title: Big Hair and Big Thoughts at a Paris Museum
description: An exhibition with over 600 items explores the evolution of women’s hairstyles, questions around body hair and more. But hair is never just hair.
content: On a recent afternoon, at an exhibition at the Museum of Decorative Arts, in Paris, two women peered into a glass case containing Andy Warhol’s wig. Mounted alongside it were more elaborate wigs belonging to less famous men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s Hot Now, and It’s Only Going to Get Hotter
description: New York is an ‘urban heat island.’ That’s not a good kind of island. Stay cool at a cooling center, a museum, or a library, officials urge. And keep the thermostat at 78.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. On a day when an excessive heat warning is in effect, we’ll see what climate change might mean for future summers in New York. We’ll also look at places where you can keep cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: ‘Mr. Blandings’ Is Now 75. What Can His Dream House Tell Us About Ours?
description: The 1948 film starring Cary Grant and Myrna Loy celebrated leaving city life and spreading out in suburbia. Even then, it was a questionable idea.
content: This year marks the 75th anniversary of one of the most hair-raising horror films ever to hit the big screen: “Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House.” Adapted from a popular 1946 novel, it tells the story of Jim and Muriel Blandings (Cary Grant and Myrna Loy), a couple climbing the walls in their cramped Manhattan apartment, who buy an old house in Connecticut that becomes a gateway to misery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Quantum Tech Will Transform National Security. It’s Testing U.S. Alliances Now.
description: A global race to harness the power of atoms for navigation, computing and encryption is pitting concerns over protectionism against the spirit of cooperation.
content: The Australian physicist shook the heavy metal box that resembled a beer cooler but held a quantum sensor. A computer screen showed that the cutting-edge device — with lasers manipulating atoms into a sensitive state — continued functioning despite the rattling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tahir Hamut Izgil
title: Let the Tragedy in My Homeland Be a Lesson
description: The defense of Uyghurs’ human rights is the defense of human rights everywhere.
content: About seven years ago, people around me started disappearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alastair Macaulay
title: Class Is in Session. The Teacher? Mark Morris.
description: The choreographer has long taught company class. It’s part of what makes his distinctly individual dancers seem so natural — and coherent as a group.
content: New York City has often been called the world’s dance capital. One good reason is that a number of the world’s foremost choreographers not only lived and worked in New York, but also taught class here. Martha Graham, George Balanchine, Merce Cunningham and many others helped to lure dancers to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: He Asked Her if She Wanted to Fall in Love. She Said Let’s Dance First.
description: Marissa Bergmann met Retta Abraham when he sat down next to her at a rooftop party. What unraveled then was a sequence of events out of an old movie.
content: Marissa Katarina Bergmann was attending a rooftop party in Bushwick, Brooklyn, in May 2021 when she was approached by a man. She had recently arrived in New York from San Francisco to visit friends. “I was sitting there with my heart-shaped sunglasses on, minding my own business,” Ms. Bergmann said, when Retta Abraham sat down next to her and started chatting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Pamela Blair, an Original ‘Chorus Line’ Cast Member, Dies at 73
description: As Val, one of the dancers in the hit Broadway musical, she sang a memorable song explaining how she got work by enhancing her body through cosmetic surgery.
content: Pamela Blair, who as the sassy and profane dancer Val in the original production of “A Chorus Line” delivered a showstopping song about enhancing her breasts and butt with silicone to get work as an actress, died on Sunday at her home in Mesa, Ariz. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jason Aldean’s Culture War Hit
description: After the country star’s “Try That in a Small Town” video was criticized as offensive, right-wing support sent the song to No. 2 on the singles chart.
content: When the country superstar Jason Aldean released his new single “Try That in a Small Town,” it was met largely with a shrug, and didn’t seem likely to become one of his signature hits. But when the song’s video was released, full of footage (actual news and stock) of disruptive crowds, criminal activity and anti-police sentiment — and a scene filmed at a site known for the 1927 lynching of an 18-year-old Black man — the song suddenly became a culture war flashpoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: Social Security’s Next Cost-of-Living Raise Is Forecast Around 3%
description: Analysts say the 2024 adjustment, which helps older Americans keep up with inflation, won’t be nearly as high as this year’s but will still be significant.
content: More than 74 million Americans can expect a healthy inflation adjustment to their Social Security benefits next year — just not as large as this year’s historic 8.7 percent raise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Donald Trump faces major new charges.
content: The office of the special counsel accused former President Donald J. Trump of seeking to delete security camera footage at his private club and residence, Mar-a-Lago, adding major accusations to an indictment charging him with mishandling classified documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Eshe Nelson
title: Europe Vowed to Make Russia Pay for the War. It’s Not That Easy.
description: Confiscating Russian state assets frozen by the United States and Europe could breach international law and set a dangerous precedent, experts say.
content: The United States and Europe have wrestled for months with the question of how to pay for Ukraine’s reconstruction from the war. As Russia pounds cities, factories and infrastructure in Ukraine, the estimated costs have swelled to $500 billion, with some experts citing numbers as high as $1 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: What’s Happening With the Quran Burnings in Sweden
description: Sweden has found itself caught between outrage over anti-Muslim actions and its commitments to free speech.
content: At least two public desecrations of the Quran in Sweden in recent weeks have provoked riots, caused a diplomatic crisis and placed a country that was long regarded as peaceful and tolerant under an awkward international spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Gathering to Show Off a New Rock Band
description: Rafael Musa and Hoang-Kim Vu reach out to us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration Moves to Tighten Fuel Economy Rules
description: The proposal is designed to help speed the country’s transition to electric vehicles, one of the president’s signature efforts to fight climate change.
content: The Biden administration on Friday formally proposed new fuel economy rules designed to accelerate the country’s transition to all-electric passenger vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Ron DeSantis and the State Where History Goes to Die
description: The history we teach to students in the present is as much about the country we hope to be as it is a record of the country we once were.
content: Last week, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was, along with his state’s Board of Education, embroiled in a controversy over a new curriculum for student instruction in African American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Judge Rejects Hong Kong’s Bid to Ban Pro-Democracy Song From Internet
description: The authorities sought a court injunction that could have pressured Google and other tech firms to remove “Glory to Hong Kong.”
content: The Hong Kong authorities suffered a surprising setback on Friday when a judge denied their request to ban a popular pro-democracy song from the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Fighting With Your Partner? Use These 4 Phrases.
description: Brevity is key, experts say.
content: Last weekend, as I was cleaning up a mess in the kitchen, my husband was parked in the living room, absorbed in his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: New Trump Charges Highlight Long-Running Questions About Obstruction
description: The accusation that former President Donald J. Trump wanted security camera footage deleted at Mar-a-Lago added to a pattern of concerns about his attempts to stymie prosecutors.
content: When Robert S. Mueller III, the first special counsel to investigate Donald J. Trump, concluded his investigation into the ties between Mr. Trump’s 2016 campaign and Russia, his report raised questions about whether Mr. Trump had obstructed his inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Evel Knievel and Minnie Mouse Catch a Wave
description: Shane Jones is a couturier of sorts for surfers who want more from the typical wet suit.
content: “A good cheetah print is hard to find.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Handy
title: Late to the Reading Circle
description: “Writing for kids had long been an ambition of mine, but until recently I didn’t know it had long been an ambition.”
content: I published my first picture book for children two years ago, when I was 62 — a bit late to the reading circle, I admit. But William Steig didn’t publish his first picture book until he was 61, and Laura Ingalls Wilder was 65 when “Little House in the Big Woods” came out in 1932, so as a late bloomer I’m in good company. The funny thing is, writing for kids had long been an ambition of mine, but until recently I didn’t know it had long been an ambition. While that might sound contradictory, remember that there is an entire industry — talk therapy — built on the idea that one’s own back story can be terra incognita.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Wall St. Pessimists Are Getting Used to Being Wrong
description: The S&P 500 is up more than 19 percent this year, but some still warn that the future may not be as rosy as that implies.
content: Beaten as they might be by the stock market’s rally, worriers on Wall Street still question how long it can last. Their numbers are shrinking, though.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Lynsea Garrison, Sydney Harper, Olivia Natt, Diana Nguyen, Shannon Lin, Paige Cowett, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Menopause Is Having a Moment
description: Our writer explains why menopause has been misunderstood by both doctors and society, and what happened after she wrote about it.
content: Some of the worst symptoms of menopause — including hot flashes, sleeplessness and pain during sex — have an established treatment. Why aren’t more women offered it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Smart Way to Turn Gambling Into a Virtue
description: Prize-linked savings accounts channel people’s love of lotteries toward financially healthy ends.
content: Gambling is foolish, we’re told, because the house always wins. Better to get rich slowly by putting a little away every day. But boy, do we love to take our chances. The American Gaming Association said last year that according to its survey, 42 percent of U.S. adults had gambled in the previous year. Sports betting is exploding. And sales of state lotteries hit $108 billion last year, up 85 percent from 2009, according to Statista.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas
title: The Life and Death of American Cities
description: Richard Ravitch showed other leaders the right ways to step up and work to save their cities.
content: Barely two months before his death in June, at 89, Richard Ravitch, the real-estate developer turned public servant, was doing the same thing he had done regularly for more than six decades: sitting at his desk in a Manhattan office and holding an in-person meeting about the future of his city. Much of Midtown was still empty, but Mr. Ravitch was not the type to work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Overhauls Military Justice Code, Seeking to Curb Sexual Assault
description: The largest overhaul of the Uniform Code of Military Justice since its creation in 1950 removes commanders’ authority over cases of sexual assault and a handful of other high-profile crimes.
content: President Biden gave final approval on Friday to the biggest reshaping in generations of the country’s Uniform Code of Military Justice, stripping commanders of their authority over cases of sexual assault, rape and murder to ensure prosecutions that are independent of the chain of command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Case for Tourism
description: When ambling abroad justifies itself.
content: Agnes Callard, a University of Chicago philosopher, infuriated various portions of the internet in June with an essay making the case against travel. Though really it was the case against tourism, since Callard exempted many forms of travel — for work or study, for personal or political reasons or charitable service — from her critique. What remained for her to savage was the contemporary there-and-back-again excursion: the checklist of foreign sights and places, the pursuit of agreed-upon Great Experiences, the expectation of some sort of personal transformation — all of it, according to her, an exercise in self-delusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: O’Connor Was a Lonely Voice for Change, Until Ireland Changed With Her
description: Sinead O’Connor shocked her strongly Catholic country when she tore up the pope’s picture. But the Church’s sexual abuse scandals made Ireland more secular, and more understanding of her criticisms.
content: When Sinead O’Connor tore up a photo of Pope John Paul II on “Saturday Night Live” in 1992, her protest caused an even bigger uproar in her native Ireland than in the United States. Thirteen years earlier, more than a million people — roughly a third of Ireland’s population — had gathered in Dublin to hear that same pope celebrate mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Aided by A.I. Language Models, Google’s Robots Are Getting Smart
description: Our sneak peek into Google’s new robotics model, RT-2, which melds artificial intelligence technology with robots.
content: A one-armed robot stood in front of a table. On the table sat three plastic figurines: a lion, a whale and a dinosaur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jean Fagan Yellin, Who Uncovered a Slavery Tale’s True Author, Dies at 92
description: Her research proved that a 19th-century book presumed to be a novel by a white woman was actually an autobiography by a formerly enslaved Black woman.
content: Jean Fagan Yellin, a historian whose six years of sleuthing revealed that what had been presumed to be a 19th-century white author’s fictional account of a young woman’s life as a slave in the American South was, in fact, a rare autobiography written by a formerly enslaved woman, died on July 19 at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Omar Hama Saley
title: Head of Presidential Guard Claims Power in Niger Coup
description: Gen. Omar Tchiani spoke on state television as the head of a transitional leadership in the West African country, two days after his troops detained the elected president.
content: The commander of Niger’s presidential guard claimed the leadership of the West African country with a televised address on Friday, two days after his military unit detained the democratically elected president and threw the future of a key Western ally in the region into uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Anello
title: An Awkward Elevator Ride Leads to Love
description: Christena Pyle and Rosemary Kalonaros spent weeks awkwardly bumping into each other at work. Then, they kissed at the company holiday party.
content: An awkward elevator ride was all Rosemary Kalonaros and Christena Pyle needed to kick-start their relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Republicans Are Resurrecting Trump’s Burisma Lie
description: The coming Biden impeachment is a farce.
content: When House Republicans return from their recess this fall, they’re likely to have an item on their agenda besides pushing the government toward shutdown: impeaching Joe Biden. “You’ve got to get to the bottom of the truth, and the only way Congress can do that is go to impeachment inquiry,” the Republican House speaker, Kevin McCarthy, said on Tuesday. Some Republicans are pretending that a mere inquiry doesn’t imply an actual impeachment, but it’s hard to imagine MAGA congressmen being satisfied with an investigation that stops short of bringing charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Mari Ruti, Scholar of Gender, Sexuality and More, Dies at 59
description: Her books explored psychoanalytic theories and a range of other topics, including the enduring popularity of a Julia Roberts movie.
content: Mari Ruti, who in wide-ranging writings on gender and sexuality found food for thought not only in psychoanalysts like Sigmund Freud and Jacques Lacan but also in online pornography, self-help books and a Julia Roberts movie, died on June 8 at a hospital near her home in Mahone Bay, Nova Scotia. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Maya Salam
title: Despite Acquittal, Kevin Spacey Faces Uphill Battle for Hollywood Roles
description: The actor, who was cleared of sexual assault charges in Britain this week, has parts in two small upcoming films. Yet his tarnished public perception makes starry roles unlikely.
content: The two-time Oscar winner Kevin Spacey said last month that he was ready to return to acting after years in the wilderness following sexual assault allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: 72 Regional Theaters, One Shared Crisis
description: Michael Paulson spoke with producers and artistic directors at nonprofit theaters across the country about the crisis their industry is facing.
content: Michael Paulson, who has covered theater for The New York Times for eight years, knew the situation was bad at the country’s nonprofit regional theaters, which had yet to regain their prepandemic audiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: Big Personalities, Small Towns and Rules Made to Be Broken
description: These novels remind us of old-fashioned human connections that can’t be severed, for better or worse.
content: Mario Fortunato’s SOUTH (Other Press, 384 pp., paperback, $18.99) has been called a family saga. But don’t expect it to be a sweeping multigenerational epic; instead, look for something more intimate. This archly observed novel, translated from the Italian by Julia MacGibbon, follows some of the conventions of the genre, allowing a well-stocked cast of characters to be buffeted by the history of 20th-century Italy, but it does so in a playful, kaleidoscopic fashion. Here the often wonderfully eccentric minor characters — chauffeurs, nursemaids, household servants — vie for center stage with the equally eccentric bourgeois clans that employ them. As Fortunato’s omniscient narrator observes at the outset, it’s “like a page out of Proust but without any aristocrats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Emmy Awards Will Be Postponed Because of Actors’ and Writers’ Strikes
description: The ceremony, originally planned for Sept. 18, may be pushed into January in hopes that the labor disputes will be settled.
content: The fallout from the Hollywood actors’ and writers’ strikes continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Strand and Monica Khemsurov
title: How to Create the Perfect Nonalcoholic Home Bar
description: From the essential spirit substitutes and how to mix them to the most striking glasses, everything you need to serve festive zero-proof cocktails.
content: It’s no secret that nonalcoholic cocktails are suddenly ubiquitous. Whereas until a few years ago, nondrinkers had to make do with cranberry-splashed club soda, now seemingly every noteworthy bar offers a Phony Negroni or a margarita-inspired mocktail. “There are so many people who are nonimbibing, for whatever reason, but who still want to be a part of the mood,” says Stacey Swenson, who designed the menu at the Swan Room bar in downtown Manhattan, which serves drinks including the Champaxne Cocktail (nonalcoholic sparkling wine, orange blossom and bitters) and the Chinola Mule (a tequila alternative with lime, passion fruit and spiced soda). The biggest change: teetotalers aren’t the only ones ordering them. “Nine out of 10 of our customers also drink alcohol,” says Nicholas Bodkins, one of the founders of Boisson, a store specializing in zero-proof spirits. “This is more of an ‘and’ than an ‘or.’” He gives credit for this shift to distillers, who, refining early iterations that often tasted soapy or medicinal, have figured out how to effectively extract the flavors of botanicals without the use of ethanol. Today, the best bitter aperitifs (the term for nonalcoholic alternatives to spirits like Campari and Aperol) have all the complexity and layered flavors of their boozy counterparts. They’re also easy to find — Boisson, for example, has locations in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco and a forthcoming Miami store, in addition to an online shop — which makes stocking a home bar with nonalcoholic options a breeze. Here, the best bottles and other ingredients to have on hand. — Oliver Strand
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 4 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 15.
content: Welcome to Week Eight of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Affordable Apartments Are Coming to the Top of New York’s Skyline
description: A deal to build the city’s newest residential skyscraper includes an unusually high number of apartments for low-income renters, plus some set aside for survivors of 9/11.
content: The latest luxury tower to rise in New York could distinguish itself not for its sky-high views, but for its residents: survivors of the Sept. 11 attacks, and some of the lowest-income renters in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Paulo Motoryn
title: Brazil Denies U.S. Extradition Request for Accused Russian Spy
description: Analysts had seen the Russian as a potential candidate in a prisoner swap with Russia, which holds two Americans on spying charges, Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan.
content: Brazil has denied the U.S. government’s extradition request for an accused Russian spy in Brazilian custody, weakening hopes that he could be used in a potential prisoner swap between the United States and Russia for either or both of two Americans being held in Russia on espionage charges that Washington considers bogus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Bank of Japan, in Surprise, Signals a Move Away From Easy Money
description: Japan’s central bank took a step toward allowing interest rates to rise, saying it will be more flexible in managing its bond market.
content: No country in the world holds as much debt as Japan, which has well over $1 trillion in U.S. government treasuries alone. Even the slightest shift to Japan’s low interest rates reverberates well beyond its borders, with the potential to drive up rates globally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Is It So Darn Hot?
description: Jennifer Szalai discusses recent books about natural history, and Jeff Goodell talks about his new climate change book, “The Heat Will Kill You First.”
content: It’s been hard to escape the feeling this summer that, after years of warnings, climate change is starting to make itself felt in everyday life: Floods, wildfires and deadly heat waves have all made headlines for months, and it looks as if July will be the hottest month ever recorded. In that sense Jeff Goodell’s book “The Heat Will Kill You First” — about the real-world costs and consequences of a warming planet — feels particularly urgent at the moment. On this week’s podcast, Goodell talks with Gilbert Cruz about air conditioning, urban heat traps and the effects of extreme heat on the human body, among other things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Two Ukrainian Service Members Take a Break to Say ‘I Do’
description: Their wedding was hosted by a charity group that provides uniforms, boots and other essentials to female soldiers, but because of demand recently started to organize such celebrations.
content: The groom could not wait to kiss the bride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa
title: They Tried to Rally South America Behind Ukraine. They Nearly Got Killed.
description: A deadly missile strike on a crowded restaurant wounded three Colombians who hope to build support for Ukraine in a continent that has avoided taking sides.
content: Héctor Abad Faciolince grew up in what had been one of the most violent cities on earth. Since Colombia won its independence more than 200 years ago, it has weathered political unrest, military crackdowns and violent drug cartels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Hugh Carter Jr., Who Pinched Pennies for a President, Dies at 80
description: While his cousin Jimmy was in the White House, his job was to make the Oval Office less imperial. Staffers called him “Cousin Cheap.”
content: Hugh Carter Jr., who helped run the presidential campaign of his cousin Jimmy Carter, then became an aide in charge of reining in the White House budget, earning the nickname “Cousin Cheap” among staff members, died on Sunday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Nate Schweber
title: In High School, Gilgo Beach Suspect Was an Angry Loner, Schoolmates Say
description: People in Massapequa Park described him as awkward, solitary, and volatile. Though few knew him well, his presence pervaded a Berner High School reunion.
content: The members of the class of 1983 slapped on their 40th reunion name tags and hit the open bar to reminisce. They squeezed into Johnny McGorey’s Pub across from the Massapequa Park train station on Long Island last weekend, among them former athletes, prom sweethearts and yearbook fixtures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Colgan
title: When Connecting With Birds Connects People
description: Readers share how organized groups improved their birding skills as well as their personal lives
content: Whether or not you’re into birds, joining a birding group can change your life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a bittersweet French comedy, a gutting Serbian social-realist drama, a Mexican true-crime doc and more.
content: Anyone with an overactive inner critic will feel seen and heard by this bittersweet debut feature from the illustrator and filmmaker Céline Devaux, which charts a middle-aged Frenchwoman’s coming to terms with grief and professional failure. As Jeanne (Blanche Gardin) deals with the aftermath of her mother’s suicide and the televised collapse of her own invention to rid the ocean of microplastics, Devaux imagines her protagonist’s anxiety as an animated figure that nags her constantly, voicing Jeanne’s worst thoughts about herself. This nifty conceit is one of the many inspired quirks that imbue “Everybody Loves Jeanne” with wit and charm, without undercutting its more serious themes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: North Carolina Trustees Say Race Can’t Be Considered in Hiring or Admissions
description: The decision by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s trustees came after the Supreme Court said affirmative action in admissions was unconstitutional.
content: Trustees for the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill voted on Thursday to bar the consideration of race in admissions and hiring, a decision that came just weeks after the Supreme Court ruled that the university’s race-conscious application process was unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Wage Growth Slowed in Second Quarter, a Sign the Economy is Cooling
description: Pay and benefits increased 1 percent, down from 1.2 percent in the first three months of the year. The cooling will be welcomed by policymakers who have been worried that rapidly rising wages could make it harder to get inflation under control.
content: Wage growth slowed this spring, the latest sign that the Federal Reserve might be succeeding in its effort to engineer a “soft landing” for the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar
title: A Facebook Internship That Led to a 650-Guest Wedding Celebration
description: In New York, Hamza Choudery and Zabreen Khan quickly bonded over a shared culture and cricket. This month they were married in Lahore.
content: Hamza Shabbir Choudery was trying to play it cool. He had casually asked his colleague Zabreen Akhtar Khan to grab a bite to eat after work one Friday in the fall of 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: So What Do Acting and Dating Have in Common?
description: Also: In Tokyo, a Japanese pop star comes out as gay to a crowd of 2,000 fans. Japan is the only G7 country that has not legalized same-sex unions.
content: “Being an actor is a constant state of putting yourself out there, hoping to be loved and hearing ‘no’ a thousand times — ‘No, you’re not right.’ ‘No, someone else is a better fit,’” Jenny Gorelick writes in this week’s Modern Love essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Hansman
title: A High-Water Year for River Rafting
description: All that snow in the West? It’s water now, and it’s providing a banner season for white-water rafting. Here are five rivers to run this summer.
content: Midmorning on the Dolores River, you could feel how recently the water had been snow. “It’s probably about 48 degrees right now,” our guide Samy said, as she carefully angled the boat so the paddlers in front got wet and she stayed dry in the back. The white water was splashy and rolling without being scary, but it picked up speed as we headed downstream.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A ‘Thoroughly American Opera’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 14 New Books Coming in August
description: Novels from Ann Patchett and James McBride, a biography of the Chinese American movie star Anna May Wong and a handful of edgy thrillers — including one about a scuba driver swallowed by a whale.
content: The story of John Ackah Blay-Miezah, a prolifically successful swindler who took advantage of Ghana’s political instability to create one of the most lucrative scams in the world during the 1970s and ’80s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Joseph
title: Three Impressive, Deceptively Easy Summer Dishes
description: The French chef Yann Nury elevates classic seasonal recipes with fresh flavor combinations and a few luxurious additions.
content: When the chef Yann Nury, 39, was growing up in Ardèche, France, summer meant a frenzy for peak-season produce. “Melons, strawberries and peaches are my childhood,” says Nury, from the loft in New York’s SoHo neighborhood that serves as his invitation-only dining room, La Residence. “For two weeks, that was almost all we ate — but only for two weeks.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Doctors Doing Risky, Unnecessary Procedures?
description: Readers discuss an article raising concerns about artery-clearing procedures. Also: Gender-neutral language; oral contraceptives; artificial intelligence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: More Charges Against Trump
description: A revised indictment details his unusual handling of classified documents.
content: Donald Trump is facing more criminal charges in a federal case accusing him of mishandling classified documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gorelick
title: Wanting More Than ‘Thank You, Next!’
description: Auditioning for romance, friendship and acting roles has a lot in common — especially when it comes to hearing “no.”
content: Our first date started at a trendy wine bar drinking rosé. At our next bar, grinding to early 2000s throwbacks, he asked if I wanted to go home with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan McKay
title: Sinead O’Connor Danced on the Edge of the Dark All Her Life
description: Auden wrote of Yeats, “Mad Ireland hurt you into poetry.” Cruel Ireland hurt O’Connor into song.
content: One night, late, during the last years of the Troubles, I was driving from the North into the Republic, along country roads and through dark villages, with “The Lion and the Cobra,” Sinead O’Connor’s debut album, blasting on the car stereo. I was singing, fired up by the thrilling energy of “Mandinka,” when I became aware of flashing blue lights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Ang Li
title: Puppy Paw Balm. An Extra Shirt. New Yorkers Cope With Hazardous Heat.
description: The heat index stayed below 100 on Friday, an unexpected salve for New York City residents who nonetheless prepared in advance.
content: As New Yorkers slogged through another day of blast-furnace July heat on Friday, some bore the benefits of advance planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Diane Wong
title: Elon’s X Machina, Crypto Orbs and a Visit to Google’s Robot Lab
description: X marks the spot where Twitter died.
content: On Sunday night, a crane arrived in downtown San Francisco to take down the Twitter sign from the company’s office building. The crane’s arrival marked the death of Twitter, the brand, and the start of X, Elon Musk’s everything app. Today, why Elon’s acquisition feels more and more like cultural vandalism and what, if anything, will replace the global town square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: ‘Swift Quake’: Taylor Swift Fans Shake Ground During Seattle Concert
description: Seismometers can pick up many types of ground vibrations but this drew comparisons to the “Beast Quake” of 2011, when Seattle football fans roared in celebration of a last-minute Seahawks touchdown.
content: “I shake it off, I shake it off,” Taylor Swift sang. And boy did her fans deliver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan Affirms Plans for Deeper Regional Ties to Counter China
description: In a defense white paper, Tokyo presents its case for engagement with allies to respond to threats posed by China and by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: China is the “greatest strategic challenge.” Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is a “serious violation of international law.” North Korea is an “imminent threat.” And Japan needs to “fundamentally” strengthen its military and work more closely with countries like South Korea to preserve regional stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: More Legal Troubles for Trump
description: Also, Ukraine retakes a village. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Donald Trump is expected take the stage tonight in Iowa at the state Republican Party’s biggest fund-raiser of the year. His presence is likely to overshadow his G.O.P. rivals there, all of whom he is currently trouncing in the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Australian TV Deal Has World Cup Viewers Asking: Where Are the Games?
description: When FIFA sold Australia’s World Cup broadcast rights to a streaming service, it made it harder for casual fans to find the matches.
content: The Women’s World Cup is by most estimates the biggest sporting event to be staged in Australia since the Sydney Olympics. FIFA, the tournament’s organizer, has trumpeted record ticket sales, and it has hailed the event both as a celebration of the popularity of women’s soccer and as a way to carry it to new fans and new markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Florida’s New Black History Standards Have Drawn Backlash. Who Wrote Them?
description: In updating the standards to comply with a new law that limits how racism can be taught, officials largely bypassed the state’s African American History Task Force.
content: When Florida set out to revamp its standards for teaching Black history this spring, a natural place to turn would have been the state’s African American History Task Force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: AIDS Relief Program Under Threat as G.O.P. Insists on Abortion Restriction
description: A decades-old program created by President George W. Bush to combat AIDS around the world is at risk of being sucked into a partisan dispute over abortion, with some Republicans threatening to block its renewal.
content: Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic former House speaker, and George W. Bush, the Republican former president, do not agree on much. But earlier this year, they joined a high-powered gathering in Washington — with the Irish rock star Bono on video from Dublin — to mark the 20th anniversary of America’s biggest and, arguably, most successful foreign aid program.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 28, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Sunday about negative online reviews of a business owned by Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Pérez misidentified her home state. As the article correctly noted, it is Washington, not Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Fire Aboard Cargo Ship off Dutch Coast Is Still Raging
description: The vessel, which has about 3,000 vehicles on board, has been burning since Tuesday. One crew member died.
content: A cargo ship that has been on fire since Tuesday near an island north of the Netherlands was still burning on Friday, the Dutch Coast Guard said, as it emerged that the vessel had been carrying significantly more electric vehicles than initially reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: In the Event of a New York City Blackout, Preparation Is Key
description: “What have you done so you’re not fumbling around in the dark?”
content: Let’s say it’s Friday night and you’re beating the 100-degree heat in New York City, watching Netflix while sitting in the direct path of a fan or an air-conditioner, when everything goes dark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The State of Women’s Soccer
description: The largest-ever Women’s World Cup tournament highlights the growing professionalization of the sport. A sportswriter shares his thoughts.
content: The FIFA Women’s World Cup is underway in Australia and New Zealand. As well as featuring more teams than any previous Women’s World Cup tournament, it has broken records for the number of tickets sold — although organizers did have to give away tickets to some underattended matches in New Zealand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How Did We Do? A Review of 2022 Before Our First Poll of 2023.
description: Trying to learn from a strong midterm run as we start surveying the G.O.P. primary.
content: Here’s a list of survey results of the 2022 midterm elections, all from the same pollster. As you read them, think about whether you think this pollster’s results were good or bad or whatever adjective you’d like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: This ‘Summer Stock’ Cast Is Having a Blast
description: The Goodspeed Opera House takes on Charles Walters’s 1950 film with zest and humor.
content: At this point we have been burned by many musical adaptations of beloved movies, and reactions have ranged from “Why did they even bother?” to “Dear God, please make it stop.” So it was with some trepidation that I traveled to the Goodspeed Opera House in Connecticut to check out its take on Charles Walters’s “Summer Stock,” from 1950.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: From a Death Investigator to Elliot Page, Memoirists Reading Their Own Words
description: Three recent audiobooks feature authors narrating their own personal stories, directly into your ear.
content: In all the audiobooks I’ve listened to at this point, I’ve decided that a narration generally falls into one of three categories. There’s the star-power option, when someone like Benedict Cumberbatch is brought in to lend weight to a production. Whole casts of voice actors might be hired to take on individual voices in nonfiction collections, like “The 1619 Project,” or expansive fiction like George Saunders’s “Lincoln in the Bardo” (which includes a staggering 166 narrators). But when it comes to an autobiography, or a personal essay collection, there really is only one best option: Hand the microphone to the author. True, not every voice is cut out to hold an audience for 10 hours, but even when untrained cadences run flat, a self-narrated memoir carries an emotional authenticity that is impossible to replicate. Here are three new memoirs skillfully narrated by their authors, only one of whom happens to be an actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: A Reeling DeSantis Takes a Swing at Scott, Now a Top Rival
description: Ron DeSantis and Tim Scott, fighting to become the leading Republican alternative to Donald Trump, have clashed in recent days over Florida’s educational standards.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida hit back on Friday at one of his leading Republican rivals, Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, accusing the senator of credulously repeating liberal criticisms over Florida’s educational standards for the teaching of slavery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Casino Mogul Steve Wynn Reaches Settlement Over Sexual Misconduct Claims
description: Mr. Wynn, who resigned from Wynn Resorts in 2018, agreed to pay Nevada $10 million and to step back from its gambling industry.
content: Steve Wynn, the longtime Las Vegas casino magnate and major Republican donor, has agreed to pay Nevada a $10 million fine and to step back from its gambling industry in a settlement related to employee allegations of sexual misconduct, closing his yearslong battle with the state’s gambling regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Ruru Kuo and James Surdam
title: Yevgeny Prigozhin: From Putin’s ‘Chef’ to His Biggest Threat
description: Yevgeny Prigozhin has transformed from one of Vladimir Putin’s closest allies to the biggest threat to face the Kremlin in decades. So how did he go from serving dinner to dignitaries to staging a rebellion against the Russian army? Valerie Hopkins explains.

title: First Responders Arrive at Capsized Passenger Ferry in the Philippines
description: Strong winds from Typhoon Doksuri capsized the vessel, killing dozens of people. The Philippine Coast Guard said they rescued at least 40.
